From Table 10, it can be observed that the SDG 13 has highest influence score while SDG 11 possesses the highest dependency score which indicates that SDG 13 can foster the progress in many goals and the progress in SDG 11 is dependent on the progress of other goal. Overall, when analyzing the SDG interaction score, SDG 7 tops among the 17 goals. Though the SDG 7 does not have higher influence score as SDG 13, it has higher SDG interaction score owing to its lesser dependency on other goal's progress. Thus, it can be inferred that focusing on SDG 7 will underpin the sustainable developments in the post-pandemic world.

Fig. 9 represents the SDG 7 interaction with other goals. The energy transition is the first and foremost step in achieving SDG 7. This creates enormous job opportunities even if the fossil fuel-based power plants are outpaced and it lessens the energy importation which would also help in boosting the economy. As renewable energy penetration increases, industries would face more demand for supporting the energy transition and innovations would have piled up in renewables with the improved collaborative circles during an accelerated transition period. Besides, if clean energy dominates in society, then the necessary climate action and clean infrastructure will prevail in the society. All these fosters the required progress in SDG 1 (No poverty), SDG 8 (Decent work and economic growth), SDG 9 (Industry, innovation and infrastructure), SDG 11 (Sustainable cities and communities), SDG 13 (Climate action), SDG 15 (Life on Land) and SDG 17 (Partnerships for the goals). Apart from the SDG 7 interaction with other SDGs, there are also interactions within other SDGs which is elucidated in Table 10. Thus, the influence of SDG 7 on other goals, in turn, be experienced on the goals which are not influenced by SDG 7 directly through various interaction mechanism. For example, the interaction of SDG 7 with SDG 9 is pivotal and SDG 9 is a crucial area of focus where most of the developments with comparatively much environmental constraints should occur. In such a case, clean energy penetration would help in revamping the environmental focused development in SDG 9 which ultimately helps the progress in environment-centered goals. This is also depicted in Fig. 9.

However, certain SDG’s progress would have a trade-off effect on the progress in SDG 7. To be clear, if the selected site for installing the renewables obstructs the ecosystem process, for instance, placing windmills in the bird migration routes, installing solar farms in a fertile region, deforesting and installing other power plants would mean none to sustainability. Hence, it is critical to consider the influence of trade-off effects especially by the SDGs 12, 13 and 15 while progressing towards a goal. In other words, effectively utilizing the resources, mitigating pollution in the value chain and supply chain and promoting the life on land should be prioritized in SDG 7. This is something that most of energy policies and strategies adopted by the authorities fails to address. A particular direction for the research community is emerging while considering this trade-off effect. Driving the innovations in recycling the solar panels and e-waste would greatly help to satisfy SDG 12 during energy transition. On the other hand, a well-established decentralized power generation scenario would eliminate the need for specific locations for power plants which all contribute to SDGs 12 and 15.

As a summary, a promising way for achieving all the SDGs is mapped from SDG 7 which originates from energy transition. Focusing on energy transition with environmental constraints would create a pollution-free energy generation and create employment opportunities and boost the economy. This also means, solving poverty issues to some extent through which energy access and affordability problems can gradually eliminated together with the influence of quality education. With the rapid expansion of clean energy scenario, green approaches in SDG 9 will be well-established and innovations, especially in recycling, reusing, converting waste energy to useful energy, improving efficiency would all play its part in imparting sustainability in every action. Other changes that the world needs, revolve around plastic usage and disposal [137]. Such problems even require each individuals’ habitual change and preferably be substituted by eco-friendly products. Finally, promoting equality in all aspects and enforcing laws, policies, strategies to achieve the same would empower the sustainable cities which on overall builds an essential structure for a sustainable world and the system becomes self-sustainable to support the rest of the goals through the best possible efforts executed on each goal.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Discussions and conclusions
ce:section.ce:para: In the wake of the pandemic, the whole sustainable development progress has been stalled and significant problems have been raised. It is evident that many solutions would emerge at this stage, but the solution which has the most sustainable characteristics should be prioritized and implemented. In this study, the global pandemic impacts are analyzed in energy sector and are correlated with their influence on sustainability progress. The technical challenges and issues faced by the energy sector include resource management, reliability and resiliency challenge on critical electrical infrastructure, variations in energy demand, change in energy consumption pattern, generation mix and market reliability, grid development/modernization work and carbon emissions. It is also observed that the fossil fuel price has fallen and it would influence energy transition at a certain level in the post-COVID scenario, especially in developing countries. Currently, the energy sector faces a dilemma either to follow the sustainable path or an economical path. It is destined to choose a sustainable path but the surrounding factors should be in a place to support such way, for example, the ultra-low interest rate for loans in developing countries to focus on renewables, tax exemption for renewable-based start-ups and the like. All the impacts and solutions infer that the investments in the post-COVID world have a huge role in shaping the futuristic world.

In the post-COVID world, to achieve SDG 7, a parallel approach is considered from the vision of renewable and energy transition, digital transformation and energy affordability. The renewable and sustainable energy transition is now needed the most than ever as such a transition would also aid in expanding the employment opportunities and drive the market dynamics in a unique way. The strategies to accelerate the transition are presented from the lens of the power plant sector, transportation sector and building sector. The direction for where prioritized investment is needed and the employment scenario as well as labor market changes that are deeply driven (positively) with the energy transition is highlighted. Digital transformation of the energy sector supports the sustainable energy sector in many ways. The need for transformation is deep-rooted and the aspects of transformation are discussed from various corners such as DER, smart grid, blockchain technology, the role of AI, ML and IoT. Then, a prominent aspect of SDG 7 dealing with energy affordability is discussed from various perspectives such as production-end, consumers-end, investors end, government and policies. All the crucial approaches derived from qualitative analysis to achieve SDG 7 is subjected to a further meta-analysis via SWOT-AHP methodology to figure out the prioritized strategy in line with current pandemic impacts. From the analysis, it can be inferred that increasing the preferences to install solar and wind energy-based projects, reskilling of labors, promoting EV penetration and decoupling the investments in fossil fuels is the priority measures that underpin the energy sustainability vision.

On the other hand, when investigating the favorability of energy sustainability in the political world, diversified approaches are carried out in both developing and developed countries. By observing the pre-pandemic political approaches and on interpreting the pandemic impact from political aspects, the post-pandemic approaches can be traced between two possible extreme scenarios as elucidated by process-tracing approach. One extreme scenario represents unilateral approaches while other extreme highlights multilateral approaches. The study claims that if the economic recovery is prioritized and renewable energy transition is avoided, then sustainability cannot be achieved in less efforts. Besides, the reality seems less promising with the weak responses to the pandemic and also with the plan for the rapid expansion of fossil fuel usage even in developed countries which exposed the weakness of multilateralism and highlighted a general preference for interest-oriented actions. To tackle this, the operational recommendations to shift the approaches towards multilateralism is also elaborated. This necessitates a paradigm shift of approaches from governments and state agencies to attain a state of balance between economic and environmental actions so as to impart the essence of multilateralism in the post-COVID recovery period. It would create a better world than a pre-COVID period or else much worse scenarios would arise if observed constraints are ignored.

The significance of achieving SDG 7 lies in hastening the progress in other goals as it possesses the highest SDG interaction score. It means that the prerequisites to support other SDGs would be well-established when the sustainable world is built with SDG 7 as a foundation. A detailed discussion of how SDG 7 would foster sustainable developments in other SDGs through SDG interaction is quantitatively presented.

The post-COVID world remains uncertain with a severe dilemma between sustainable development and economic development. Identifying common grounds and executing them remains effective in the recovery period while when a normal situation regains, much focus is required to be given for sustainable development. Whether achieving the SDGs within 2030 is possible or not, putting maximum efforts to attain them is what matters the most and should be the prioritized goal. Through this study, the authors suggest to vision sustainable development through the lens of energy sustainability.
